title: Swastika destroyed in Valley View case of mistaken identity
text:
Security cameras have captured a delivery driver on video appearing to wipe a swastika design from an Adelaide veranda.

But the disappointed homeowners have revealed the symbol was a Hindu sign of luck and welcoming rather than a neo-Nazi declaration of hatred.

They said the intricate work took hours to create and was in fact celebrating the Hindu holiday Diwali this weekend.

Called a rangoli, such artworks involve the creation of detailed designs using coloured powders, sand and rice.

This one prominently featured a swastika, a symbol with thousands of years of history considered by members of the Hindu religion as a sign of welcome and luck.

The homeowner, who did not wish to be named, and his wife arrived back at their Valley View home to find their symbol destroyed on Sunday.

Security camera footage of the front of the house showed a deliveryman looking at the symbol intently before swiping his foot across it, destroying the swastika.

media_camera The Diwali rangoli which was destroyed outside an Adelaide home.

The homeowner, whose wife spent hours making the symbol, told The Advertiser he could understand the man’s confusion and wanted to tell him what the symbol means in the Hindu religion.

“I got the message about what he was trying to do because he only tried to wipe the swastika area, he didn’t touch anywhere else,” he said.

“I think it was pretty clear that he didn’t know the meaning of the swastika to us and that he was just trying to wipe it away.

“So I just wanted to try and get the message out there for both communities, it's a good chance to explain what the symbol means.

“The swastika means prosperity and wealth, it also means the sun and spreading light into your own life and someone else’s life. So it is a symbol of doing good for others.”

media_camera The "deliveryman" was seen wiping away the design with his foot.

The homeowner said his wife was upset when she saw the destroyed symbol.

“I was pretty calm when I saw it but my wife was devastated,” he said.

“We live very kindly and happily and the rangoli was a sign of welcoming all the people to the house.

“I tried to explain to her that the guy who did it was not wrong, but he was also not correct, because he just had a misunderstanding.”

The swastika has been a spiritual symbol for multiple cultures for more than 5000 years.

A rotated version was appropriated by the Nazi party after World War I and became associated with the Holocaust and millions of deaths during World War II.
description: A deliveryman has been caught on CCTV wiping away what he appeared to think was a piece of vile neo-Nazi imagery on an Adelaide doorstep. It was actually an ancient Indian religious symbol.
